thread.title: The best part-time summer jobs for students

author: Josie Gurney-Read
title: The best part-time summer jobs for students
text: For more money tips, visit The Axis » Let’s face it; we could all use a few extra pennies – or pounds – in our back pockets for the occasional treat, but earning that cash, especially when you’re still a student, can be hard. If you’ve got a few hours to spare at the weekend, or fancy filling the long summer with something other than Netflix, then a part-time job could be for you. The positives with being employed to do something you’re passionate about are hard to ignore... Enjoy sport? Then you could consider sports coaching. You will need to hold a recognised coaching qualification and a CRB check if you plan to work with children. If you’re lucky, the cost of the first level of the qualification, may be picked up by the club you intend to help at. The positives associated with being employed to do something you’re passionate about are hard to ignore, and once you have the certificate it’s a job you can continue to capitalise on through university. Another option that, once again, requires certification, is lifeguarding. You will need to be a strong swimmer and hold the National Pool Lifeguard Qualification (NPLQ), or the RLSS National Beach Lifeguard Qualification ; however, it’s a good option for those looking for long term, continous employment. Office work might sound like the opposite end of the spectrum, but working in administration has its benefits. The hours are likely to be fixed, you’ll get valuable experience to put on your CV, and weekend working is rare. While it can be monotonous, the contracts can often be fixed term, so you’ll have an endpoint in sight. Register your interest at a recruitment agency, such as Reed – and make sure you regularly call in to check for available vacancies – or make direct contact with the businesses themselves via their HR departments. Get the word out by leafleting your area or by joining the ranks on Gumtree Alternatively, if you want to work for yourself, you could take up dog walking. While it may take a while to build up a reputation, you’ll be able to set your own rates per dog, per hour (anywhere between £10 and £15 is realistic). Get the word out by leafleting your area or by joining the ranks on Gumtree . You could also sign up to Tailster.com to help get those initial bookings. Make sure you check out your local council’s guidelines, as some areas will have limits on the number of dogs you can walk at once. Seasonal work is another great way of earning some extra cash, but without the need to commit long term. Farm work and fruit picking are good places to start, with jobs normally lasting around two weeks. Some places will pay by the hour, while others pay depending on the amount you pick. If you don’t fancy manual labour but still enjoy being active, summer camp work could be for you. While the number of roles you can take on will be limited before you reach 18, you could qualify to be a camp counsellor; looking after both home and overseas students. Board and lodging is usually included, so you’ll be able to save pretty much all that you earn during your employment. Camp Beaumont , for example, offers staff positions to 17-year-olds as assistant group leaders, paying £142.13 per week. Check out e4s.co.uk for more opportunities. ...make sure you ask around before accepting a job, to find a level of pay you are happy with Now for the serious bit; there are certain rules that apply if you’re under the age of 18. If you’re still at school, you can only work 12 hours a week during term time, including a maximum of two hours on school days and Sundays, and eight hours on a Saturday. During the holidays this rises to 35 hours a week. It’s also important to note that you will not be entitled to the National Minimum Wage until you turn 16 and reach school leaving age, so make sure you do some asking around before accepting a job, to find a level of pay you are happy with. Once you are 16, and above school leaving age, you are entitled to £3.79 an hour. This rises to £5.13 an hour when you reach the age of 18. • Find more tips for studying, working and gap years on The Axis
